We provide a categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The approach is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. It is based on a set of axioms that guarantee that a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. The axioms are similar to those of von Neumann, Mackey, and Piron. The approach is illustrated by a reconstruction of quantum mechanics from a few simple axioms.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that have been hypothesized to be the result of a single evolutionary transition from a free-living organism to a parasitic one. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two distantly related species of myxozoans. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister group to the less reduced Polypodium hydriforme. In addition, we show that myxozoans have one of the smallest reported animal genomes and that gene content and expression are reduced relative to other parasitic cnidarians. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This may be a general feature of parasitic cnidarians. COVID-19 is a disease caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The disease is a serious global health problem. The virus has been shown to be able to block the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, which are key factors in the activation of the IFN response. In this study, we show that the accessory protein Orf6 of SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. We show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain. We also show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. Our results unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This mechanism may be a target for the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion people by the middle of the 21st century. To feed this population, the global food system will have to produce more food with less water and less greenhouse gas emissions. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. This variability will increase the risk of food insecurity in these countries and, in particular, the risk of food price spikes. These results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding maize for heat tolerance. They also highlight the importance of considering the impact of climate change on the stability of global grain trade and international grain prices. This will be especially important in the context of the recent rise in food prices. (Show more)

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savannas. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of species-level identification of plant remains in traditional studies. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that the extent of food-plant species partitioning was strongly dependent on the proportion of grass consumption, and that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest dietary overlap. These results suggest that the extent of food-plant species partitioning may be more limited than is currently assumed, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the management of large mammal populations and the conservation of African savanna biodiversity. (Show more)

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Moreover, businesses have widely differing beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many businesses plan to seek funding through the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major concern for the marine environment. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks, which remove plastic fragments of millimeters in size. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is one of the most fundamental questions in presolar grain research. We determined the ages of 40 large SiC grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We find that the majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This indicates that the sun was not yet formed when the grains condensed. Our results provide insights into the formation of the early solar system. This article is protected by copyright. The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased exponentially. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The expansion of the global fishing fleet is likely to continue in the coming decades, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder with a poor prognosis. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We report here the results of a proof of concept study in a mouse model of MSA, in which we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation and to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of VX-765 to slow down the progression of MSA. This study also opens the door to a phase I/II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy. This trial will be able to confirm the safety and the potential efficacy of VX-765 in MSA patients. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the body. It is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system, including control of blood pressure, regulation of inflammation, and control of the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between blood and tissue. The endothelium is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources, and to coordinate responses of the entire vascular system. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected in a network, and that the network is highly efficient in the transmission of information. The network is also highly dynamic, with short path lengths and high synchronizability. These findings reveal the nature of the endothelial communication system and its role in the control of the cardiovascular system. They also provide a model for the design of communication networks in other biological and technological systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated a vast amount of data, which are being used to monitor and respond to the pandemic. However, the data are often difficult to access and use. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides a common interface to a large number of data sources, including deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format, which allows for easy integration with other data sources and for the development of new applications. We provide examples of how the data can be used to monitor the pandemic. The data are available at https://covidcast.org.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling and that its substitution with Alanine leads to a complete loss of C-type inactivation gating. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. It also provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the K+ channel family. This work may also have implications for the design of drugs that target K+ channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. In this study, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, synthesize a variety of natural products. These natural products could be used as a source of therapeutics or as a basis for the development of new therapeutics.

Anxiety is a common feature of psychiatric disorders and is known to influence social behavior. However, the underlying mechanisms are largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in rats and identify an important role for brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens. We demonstrate that high-anxious animals are less likely to become dominant and that this is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further show that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, enhances brain energy metabolism and prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and opens up new avenues for the development of treatments for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with programmable responses is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to discover structures that are composed of multiple materials with distinct properties and seamlessly collaborate to produce the target responses. The structures are digitally synthesized and effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of programmable structures. It is expected to inspire the development of new materials and structures for various applications.

The hemoglobin pattern in human blood is a reflection of the developmental stage of the hematopoietic system. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the erythroid lineage and can reverse the adult hemoglobin pattern in human erythroblasts. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be a potential target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for the resistance of cancer cells to ferroptosis. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The underlying mechanisms of hypertension-induced heart failure are complex and not fully understood. Here, we show that the major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) activate store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our findings suggest that LCCBs may be a potential target for the treatment of heart failure.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP had little effect on the conservation of older-forest–associated birds, but did halt the decline of early-seral–associated birds. However, the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older forests, and early-seral ecosystems are still being lost. The NWFP is a unique case study for evaluating the influence of policy on biodiversity.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the pharmaceutical industry. Here, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The design strategy is based on the prediction of the membrane permeability, binding affinity to the ribosome, and solubility of the designed compounds. We show that the designed compounds are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens and are up to 56 times more active than telithromycin. The best compound designed by us is more accessible, exhibits higher binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. The design strategy can be used to develop new antibiotics for the treatment of antibiotic-resistant infections. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new architecture for deep learning that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a simple idea: use dilated convolutions to capture features at different scales, and densely connect all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several problems. The code is available at this https URL .

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become ubiquitous in the past 50 y. However, the impact of this technology on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-decouples the circadian clock and suppresses melatonin. This has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is a 1,300-y period of global climate change that is often attributed to a single bolide impact. However, the YDB cooling is also characterized by a distinctive suite of magnetic grains and microspherules that are thought to be of extraterrestrial origin. Here, we show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of these grains and microspherules is consistent with terrestrial sources. In addition, we show that the YDB spherules are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America, which is consistent with the source of the magnetic grains and microspherules. These results suggest that more than one bolide impact may be required to explain the YDB cooling. (Read more)

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that the absence of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. This was not fatal, but led to the development of autoimmune diseases. We also show that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice had opposing impacts on induced autoimmune models. Thus, although CTLA-4–deficient mice had more severe collagen-induced arthritis, they were protected against peptide-induced experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis. These results indicate that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses, and its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, using a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes. Our results show that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These results have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of animal diversity and the origins of plant feeding in insects. They also suggest that the evolution of plant feeding in insects may have been key to the origin of beetle diversity. © 2017, The Author(s). All rights reserved.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-’s variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also be relevant to other emerging viruses and their variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that the size of the population did have an effect on the variation in plane performance and the ability to access better-adapted planes. These results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. This study also highlights the importance of trial-and-error learning to the innovation and adaptation of artifacts. Our results have implications for the design of experiments and the interpretation of results in the field of cultural evolution. They also have implications for the design of education and training programs that aim to enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of individuals and populations. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the APOE ε4 allele. APOE is a protein that is produced by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. We found that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning, whereas APO4 decreases it. APOE4 is associated with increased risk for AD, but the mechanism of this association is unknown. Our results suggest that APOE4 may be associated with increased risk for AD because of increased accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain. This hypothesis is supported by the finding that APOE4 increases the rate of accumulation of complement-coated senescent synapses in the brain.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 1,200 km. It is the densest part of the Earth. The formation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. The nucleation of the inner core is a key step of the inner core formation. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. In this study, we found that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be two-step. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase, which is the first stable phase of iron. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. This study provides a new perspective for understanding the formation of the inner core. It also provides a new idea for the study of the formation of other dense materials. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common features of marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also the most complex cognitive skill we have. How the human brain processes language is therefore a fundamental question of cognitive neuroscience. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can predict brain responses to sentences in the human brain during language processing. This suggests that predictive processing may be a fundamental mechanism in the brain’s computation of language.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it has been shown that there are problems that cannot be solved by DL. This paper shows that this is not because of instability of DL, but rather because there is no algorithm that can solve the problem. This is a fundamental result that will have a major impact on the field of machine learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. The scientific community is currently debating the causes of the pandemic. One of the most prominent arguments is that people’s inability to understand exponential growth is the main cause of the pandemic. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. The experiment’s critical design flaws are discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a chronic disease that can be cured with antibiotics. However, the causative agent is still unknown. Here, we report the genome sequence of a human pathogen, M. lepromatosis, which is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We also show that M. lepromatosis and M. leprae, the leprosy pathogens, are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of leprosy. (Read more)

The evolution of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is a fundamental question of fundamental importance. It is also a very difficult one, as it is usually studied in the limit of infinite system size. We show that, in the space–time scaling limit, the entanglement dynamics can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is exact for integrable systems, and it is supported by numerical results for a paradigmatic model. We believe that it will be useful for the study of entanglement dynamics in a broad class of systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 500,000 people worldwide. The only vaccine currently available for use in humans is the messenger RNA (mRNA)-based vaccine, which requires cold storage. This study describes a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that can be manufactured at room temperature and is therefore more accessible to the general population. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but the attenuated virus grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is highly protective in a relevant hamster model and can be used for mass vaccination programs. This vaccine has the potential to save millions of lives. (Show more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It has been responsible for the deaths of millions of people in the past and continues to be a threat to human health today. In this study, we develop a mathematical model to understand the spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). Our results suggest that human ectoparasite vectors, such as fleas and lice, were the primary transmission pathways for plague during this period. This finding challenges the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats, which is the most common vector in modern plague epidemics. Our results highlight the importance of studying the history of plague transmission to understand the dynamics of this disease in the past and inform the development of control strategies for the present and future epidemics. The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of neuroscience. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the ability to process information, is less understood. Here, we show that the evolution of brain power is not only different from that of brain size but also more complex. We show that the evolution of brain power is characterized by four major shifts in the scaling of brain neurons. The most important shift is the increase in brain neuron numbers in birds and mammals, which is a result of the evolution of a new type of neuron.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Thus, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria may be more complex than previously appreciated. This may have important implications for the design of TRAP1-targeted therapies. (Read more)

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton. They are dynamic, and their structure and function are regulated by a number of proteins. One of these proteins is cofilin, which is responsible for the disassembly of actin filaments. Here, we show that cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, which is relevant to cells. We show that the mechanical state of the filament network can be used to control the severing rate of cofilin. This mechanism is critical for the function of cofilin in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, the sugar found in many foods and beverages. However, the results of this study suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be more complex than previously thought.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its history. It is the only island in the world that is part of both the African and the Asian plate. This unique location has led to a unique history, with a settlement from both Africa and Asia. We show that the settlement was not a gradual process but happened in a few centuries. In addition, we show that the settlement was not homogeneous across the island, with a stronger influence of Africa in the west and of Asia in the east. This is the first study to show the influence of geography on the genomic diversity of a population. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This is a form of emotional contagion that is not dependent on in-person interaction or nonverbal cues. This work suggests that people’s emotions are more malleable than previously thought, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. It also suggests that the use of social networks may be a useful tool for the prevention and treatment of emotional disorders.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been shown to impact protein synthesis. However, the impact of modifications in coding regions on translation has not been well characterized. Here, we show that the presence of a chemical modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We find that the presence of a chemical modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also find that the presence of a chemical modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis.

This study shows that the subjective feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive health and well-being outcomes. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of aquatic lifestyles has been a major driver of the evolution of mammals. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and the fossil record to test the extent to which aquatic lifestyles have driven the evolution of body size in mammals. We find that the evolution of aquatic lifestyles is driving the evolution of body size in mammals toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment. These results have implications for the evolution of body size in other organisms and for the evolution of mammals in particular.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a more favorable environment for virus growth at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity. However, the molecular basis for this temperature dependence has not been elucidated. Here we show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a more robust antiviral defense response at 37 °C than at 33 °C. This difference in the strength of the antiviral response accounts for the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication. Our findings have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Read more)

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanism is used to regulate the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. We propose a mechanochemical model where the mechanical activity of type IV pili is sensed by a chemosensory system, which in turn regulates the activity of type IV pili. This mechanism is used by P. aeruginosa to sense surfaces and promote its pathogenicity.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. This has led to a substantial increase in the presence of pesticides in surface waters. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the presence of pesticides in surface waters and the risk of pesticide effects on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface waters is high and that the risk of pesticide effects on biodiversity is substantial. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the global pesticide problem and is a call for action to improve pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread to more than 210 countries and territories. Deer are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection, and experimentally infected fawns can transmit the virus. We report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in 33% of free-living deer and 82.5% of deer sampled during the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic in Iowa. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This approach is critical to prevent the emergence and spread of zoonotic pathogens. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still debated. Here, we show that neurons are the major source of inflammatory factors in AD, which may precede the formation of Aβ plaques. Our results suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be a key event in the development of AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a new and unique archaeological record of chicken exploitation from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel. The results of our faunal analysis show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread in the Hellenistic period. This is supported further by a survey of chicken remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.
The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. The results of this study provide new insights into the folding of a large protein.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap formed by Np4 in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 to accumulate to high levels. We also show that the enzyme responsible for removing capped RNAs in other contexts, RppH, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress. This enzyme prefers capped RNAs as substrates over their capped counterparts, and the cap is removed in a manner distinct from the one used to remove capped RNAs in other contexts. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during disulfide stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression. We found that citrulline, an amino acid that is derived from arginine, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study may also have implications for other conditions in which arginine deprivation is involved, such as cancer. (Read more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental property of the planet. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of the biosphere is concentrated in a few taxa, and that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system can be in a critical state, and the system’s dynamics are independent of the initial conditions. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain. This opens up opportunities to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond via strain engineering. This work provides a new route to control the properties of diamond, which can be used for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest for the development of new classes of fungicides. Here, we report the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, which are highly diverse in sequence and structure. The structure of one of the peptides was solved by NMR spectroscopy. The peptide exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of the peptide was revealed by microscopy and phosphoinositide binding studies. The discovery of this new class of antifungal peptides may lead to the development of a new class of fungicides. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm by providing a source of proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a model for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences in the context of the male–female reproductive axis. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is critical for the coagulation system. It is also important for the adhesion of platelets to the vessel wall. The protein has a large number of domains, and the function of many of them is unknown. We show that the protein can be switched between two states by force. This mechanism may be important for the regulation of VWF function.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the subject of intense study for the past decade. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that associate with humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. Here, we present a database of human-associated viruses, which is the first of its kind. We show that the human virome is highly associated with disease, and we provide a resource for future studies of the human virome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL can measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate the ACI. The results show that the HSRL can provide new insights into the ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The origin and evolution of life are among the most fundamental questions in science. In this study, we use the thermostability of ancestral enzymes to reconstruct the paleoenvironment of ancient life. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. This study demonstrates the potential of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. We believe that this approach will be of interest to a broad audience and will be of use to many other research groups. We hope that it will inspire others to apply similar methods to other important questions in science. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Ion channels are the main ion-conductive proteins in the cell membrane. They are responsible for the flow of ions across the membrane and are involved in many physiological and pathological processes. The K+ channel BK is a large-conductance calcium-activated potassium channel that is normally closed and inactivated by C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel is open and inactivated by C-type inactivation. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of K+ channels. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 1 million deaths occurring each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion of the red blood cell (RBC), the site of infection. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the RBC surface, which in turn reduces a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding has major implications for the design of new anti-malarial drugs and could lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention of malaria. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized by applying strain. We also show that the bandgap of diamond can be tuned by strain. Our findings open up opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for applications in electronics, photonics, and energy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe influenza virus infection. We found that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of dry air on host defense and disease outcome during influenza infection. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in the form of a tree, but there is no direct evidence that this is the case. Here, we show that the brain responds to the addition of each word in a sentence in a similar way, suggesting that the brain applies a merge operation to phrases of arbitrary complexity. We also show that the brain responds to the addition of each word in a sentence in a similar way, suggesting that the brain applies a merge operation to phrases of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental step in the construction of meaning.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in development and disease. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its activity is regulated by phosphorylation. We show here that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the pathway. This may be a common mechanism in redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons and dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. We also found that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the peri-LH region, and dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would be a major advance in agriculture. Here, we have developed a system for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley. We have shown that the plant can control the expression of genes in the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, and that this control can be used to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in situ. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is in the midst of a deforestation crisis. The causes of this crisis are complex and multifaceted, but one of the most important is the lack of effective monitoring of the region’s forests. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to address this problem. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in it. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the program may have had no effect in some communities. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to sense the world around them. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36(±0.06) °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. Our results indicate the potential benefits of a phaseout of fossil fuels and other anthropogenic sources.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on global health. The development of vaccines is a critical step in containing the pandemic. Here we report the design and characterization of a recombinant protein subunit vaccine candidate that can be produced at large scale and is capable of inducing an immune response against the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. This vaccine candidate can be used to develop vaccines against other coronaviruses. This work provides a potential solution to the global access issue of vaccines. Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is difficult to treat and has a poor prognosis. In the last years, it was shown that mutations in anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) are involved in the pathogenesis of neuroblastoma. We show here that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is activated by secreted ALKALs. We further show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the neural crest. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/Ltk signaling in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This is an important step towards the development of zebrafish as a model system for the study of neuroblastoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of plague is one of the most mysterious in the history of life on Earth. The emergence of Yersinia pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a story that has been told many times, but the details of its evolution and ecology are still unknown. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a much larger dataset to explore the history of plague. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. This study also reveals the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for the study of gender, race, and class in the United States. (PsycInfo Database Record

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a key question in climate change mitigation. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage in the top 15 cm of soil, but the magnitude of the effect depends on the type of crop and the soil management system. We also show that the management of pastures can increase the storage of both particulate and mineral-associated SOC. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to store carbon in the soil and provide a framework for the design of climate-smart agricultural systems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to cause epidemics and pandemics. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of zoonotic potential can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a framework for the systematic identification of zoonotic potential of emerging and reemerging viruses. It can be used to prioritize research and public health interventions to prevent and control future outbreaks. This work is a first step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that can attract pollinators and increase the rate of pollination. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that the red color of the nectar is attractive to the most likely pollinators of this species, Phelsuma geckos. This work provides evidence for the convergence of this trait in two species of plants visited by hummingbirds. This convergence suggests that the red color of nectar is a trait that is favored by natural selection and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. The history of Europe is marked by a series of migrations and invasions, which have shaped the genetic structure of the population today. However, the history of the population during the period between the migrations and invasions is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had been deformed by cranial cranial deformation. Our results indicate that they had a genetic ancestry that was not typical for the population of the time. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This indicates that the history of the population during the period between the migrations and invasions is more complex than previously thought.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of MERS-CoV and the potential risk of HKU4 and HKU5 for human infections. They also

We report the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate a large cohort of febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the potential for rapid deployment of public health response. This approach can be used to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study also highlights the need for a global effort to standardize and harmonize mNGS data and bioinformatics. This will enable the rapid identification of emerging pathogens and the development of a global mNGS database. This will be critical to the rapid deployment of public health response. The human lagging strand polymerase, pol δ, is responsible for replicating the template of the Okazaki fragments. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for lagging strand replication. (Read more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this paper, we report the first demonstration of the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We use computer vision to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, we find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. We also find that neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Finally, we find that neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward the development of a comprehensive understanding of the physical dynamics of cities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment is mainly supportive. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal. The ability of fungi to sense and respond to copper is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in this process is less well understood. Here we report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This work demonstrates the existence of a previously unknown role for fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work also highlights the potential of natural products to be used as a tool for the study of metal homeostasis in fungi. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The formation of tridymite in a sedimentary environment is rare. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and the amorphous silica, and is possibly derived from a silicic volcanic source. The amorphous silica is cogenetic with the other primary and secondary minerals and is possibly derived from multiple aqueous solutions. The presence of tridymite, amorphous silica, and magnetite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, suggests that the sedimentary rocks in the region are primary and not the result of a later impact.

Frost events are a major cause of crop and forest losses, and their frequency is expected to increase in a warmer world. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are linked to their geographic distribution. These findings can be used to predict the future distribution of frost events and the vulnerability of forests to frost damage. Our results can be used to inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells are poorly understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains a predominantly IL-17A+ phenotype and is required for the development of colitis, whereas the other subset, which is dependent on Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors, is required for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This study provides insight into the developmental origins of Th17 cells and their role in inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, and the disease course is variable. There is a need for disease modeling and drug screening to identify potential therapies. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. This will enable high-throughput drug screening to identify potential therapies. This method will also enable disease modeling and the study of the disease mechanism. This will lead to the development of new therapies for ALS. (Read more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is an important factor in the transmission of infectious agents to hosts. Here, we show that the tick-borne bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum alters the gut microbiota of its vector, the blacklegged tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the vector. We demonstrate that the bacterium induces the vector to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, which is a key obstacle for the bacterium. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early history of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin and evolution of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we report a new basal member of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”). This new taxon, named Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the origin of the short tail in birds. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. The climate system is very sensitive to the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere. This is because water vapor is the dominant greenhouse gas. However, the climate system is also very sensitive to the amount of water vapor in the stratosphere. This is because the stratosphere is the region of the atmosphere where most of the water vapor is found. We show here that the amount of water vapor in the stratosphere increases with the temperature of the troposphere, which is a sign of a positive feedback.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. In some species, the color of the animal is determined by the presence of pigments in the skin. In others, the color is determined by the presence of pigments in the bones. In this study, we show that the presence of pigments in the bones of anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history. We describe the molecular and functional basis of this phenomenon, which we call chlorosis.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the mechanisms that regulate the tumor microenvironment in response to hypoxia are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a key factor in the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells. This study provides insight into the mechanisms that regulate the tumor microenvironment in response to hypoxia. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skin for parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method for the identification of the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to extract protein from the parchment surface and subsequent analysis by mass spectrometry. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that the use of fetal animal skin for parchment was not as widespread as has been suggested. The method described here could be used to study the animal origin of other materials, such as paper, that are often made from the same animal species. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This study establishes an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Show more

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in the regulation of various biological processes. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in the spike protein of currently circulating viruses. We have determined the structure of the D614G spike and show that it adopts a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the host cell receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. These results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike protein and may help to inform the design of future vaccines and antiviral drugs. We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate the impact of COVID-19 on life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity. Our projections indicate that the Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. These findings underscore the importance of addressing structural inequalities in health outcomes. (PsycInfo Database Record

Fire is a key natural process in many ecosystems, but its effects on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of global fire activity. This has implications for the climate system, as it can reduce warming. However, the risk of more extreme fires, especially in drylands, means that fire management needs to be considered in future fire projections.
