Text data are ubiquitous and often contain latent patterns that can be used to understand the data and make predictions. However, the patterns are often difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the Black Death in the 14th century, lasted for more than four centuries. The origin of this disease is still debated, with the most widely accepted hypothesis being that it was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in the Asian source region were favorable for the emergence of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, and that the disease was repeatedly introduced into Europe via its Asian reservoirs. We find no evidence for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results have important implications for the understanding of the history of plague in Europe. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web. They are important as a food source for a variety of species, including sea stars, and are also prey for a number of predators. In the past few years, a disease has emerged that has led to the rapid death of many asteroids. We show that the disease is caused by a virus. We also show that the virus is present in the environment and in other echinoderms, suggesting that it can spread between asteroids and other species.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor prognosis. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. Here, we show that a monoclonal antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is effective in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects, and we show that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP can be used to target AML cells, which is important for the development of antibody-based therapies. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (Read more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its history. It is the only island in the world that is part of both the African and the Asian plate. This unique location has led to a unique history, with a settlement by humans from both Africa and Asia. We present a high-resolution view of the genomic diversity of the Malagasy people, which allows us to study the history of the island and the settlement of Madagascar.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. We found that the RNA also represses two additional genes, cadA and galE, by base pairing with the 5′-UTR. The translation of the RNA is also regulated by the base pairing. The translation and base-pairing functions compete, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate metabolism. (Read more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-’s variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also be relevant to other emerging viruses and their variants.

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system. They provide the USDA with crop condition data that is used to estimate crop yields. However, the data is subjective and categorical, and is not amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the data can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We also show that the data is stable over time, and can be used to predict crop yields with high accuracy. Finally, we show that the data can be used to monitor crop conditions and predict crop conditions earlier than the official USDA forecasts.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, the response of soil respiration to warming is highly variable across studies, and the mechanisms behind this variability remain unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. This lack of acclimation in respiration across biomes and decades of warming suggests that soil respiration may not be a major driver of future increases in global temperatures. However, the consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. This study adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the origin and diversification of life. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the loss of genes, and that the loss of genes is linked to the establishment of the parasitic lifestyle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change to water security. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. This increase in drought risk is projected to increase further under future high-emission scenarios. The results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This study provides a useful tool for assessing the impact of climate change on water security in SSA. It also provides a benchmark for evaluating the effectiveness of adaptation strategies. The discovery of a new quasicrystal in trinitite, the first material to be formed by nuclear fusion, is a milestone in the history of quasicrystals. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, in red trinitite, the oldest known anthropogenic material, provides a link between the discovery of the first quasicrystal and the discovery of the first artificial diamond.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth. It is powered by the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The conversion of this energy is mediated by the modified tetrapyrroles, the most abundant class of organic molecules on Earth. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. We also found that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycInfo Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record. We show that the occurrence of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of drought has increased because of human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal pathways that lead to the core autistic symptoms. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for the identification of the causal pathways that lead to the core autistic symptoms. It also provides a model system for the study of the underlying mechanisms of autism. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the first to our knowledge to report on the prevalence of negativity biases in a large, cross-national sample of the general public. It also provides the most comprehensive demonstration of individual-level variation in this regard. The results are important for understanding the nature of the news media, and for the way in which they shape our political world.

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder of unknown cause. Here, we report that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 result in a Stormorken-like syndrome of congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. We show that the mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1 result in gain- or loss-of-function of the CRAC channel, respectively. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to neurons. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spreading of aggregates can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of spreading and the potential therapeutic targets for neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The bat’s saliva contains a large number of immunologically privileged factors, which are important for the survival of bats. However, the factors that contribute to the immunologically privileged function of bat saliva are still unclear. In this study, we found that the bat’s submandibular salivary gland contains a protein that inhibits the immune response and facilitates viral infection. Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth. One-carbon units are essential for cell growth, and are provided by the folate cycle. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of the folate cycle enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase. We show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer, and that the cancer cell response to the inhibitor is dependent upon the cancer cell’s ability to import glycine. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited for cancer therapy.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous motor neuron disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS is a general feature of the disease. This may be a consequence of the unique cellular environment of the motor neuron, which is a highly specialized cell type with a limited capacity for protein homeostasis. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work opens up a new platform for the study of many-body physics with neutral atoms. It also provides a new approach for the design of photonic crystals for applications in quantum information processing. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the role of aquatic habitats in this diversification is still controversial. Here we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous that is sister to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that lived below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. This study raises questions about the very early diversification of the flowering plants and the role of aquatic habitats in this diversification.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology. However, the evolution of viruses has been difficult to study, as they are usually present in low copy numbers and are difficult to isolate. Here we show that ancient viral sequences can be used to study the evolution of viruses. We show that ancient viral sequences can be used to study the evolution of viruses.

Sea level is rising on a global scale, and this rate is accelerating. This acceleration is due to the melting of glaciers and ice caps and the expansion of the ocean’s ice-free area. The rate of acceleration is consistent with the rate of warming of the climate system.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain is more common in midlife than in today’s elderly, and that this pattern is seen across education and occupation. The erosion of working-class life in America is reflected in the erosion of working-class pain.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the fate of the leaving group in a key reaction of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of enzyme intermediates. The study also demonstrates the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in the study of the reaction of a nonnatural substrate. The results of this study will be of interest to enzymologists and structural biologists. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the mortality rate is high. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug used for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great benefit to the global community. The development of effective antiviral treatments for coronavirus diseases is a global priority. This article is protected by copyright. This work is about the power of the mind to shape the world. It is also about the power of the world to shape the mind. In the first experiment, teachers who were trained to adopt an empathic mindset about student misbehavior reported more positive student behavior and were less likely to suspend students. In the second experiment, students who were trained to respond empathically to misbehavior reported more positive student behavior and were more likely to respect their teachers. In the field experiment, students in schools that received the intervention had half the suspension rate of students in schools that did not. These findings have implications for the future of education.

DNA alkylation is a major cause of mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this work, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. We found that the minor-groove alkylation is a major cause of transcriptional stalling. In addition, we found that the minor-groove alkylation is a major cause of transcriptional mutagenesis. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This work will be helpful for the development of new strategies for cancer prevention and treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that sequential proteolysis of the S proteins is required for MERS-CoV infection of human lung-derived cells, but not of other cell types. This requirement for sequential proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. These findings suggest that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. This study also provides a model for the design of future studies of the role of sequential proteolysis in virus infection. (Read more)

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to the sustainability of the planet. However, the food system is also a major driver of obesity and other health problems. Here, we show that a simple change to the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering operation can have a large impact on the proportion of meals that are vegetarian. This has the potential to make a significant contribution to the sustainability of the planet and to the health of the population.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the surfaceome of a panel of six of the most prominent oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. We find massive oncogene-induced changes to the glycoproteome and differential increases in complex hybrid glycans, especially for KRAS and HER2 oncogenes. Overall, these studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a powerful approach for studying the cell surface and its remodeling in cancer. It also provides a resource for the cancer research community to identify potential surface targets for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward a comprehensive understanding of the cell surface in cancer.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We also find that vote-by-mail does not appear to increase the likelihood of voter fraud.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its spread and severity is unknown. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. We show that the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein is similar to that of SARS-CoV, but with the addition of two unique interfaces. These interfaces may allow for the formation of unique large-scale assemblies, which may be important for immune evasion and spread. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the spread of the virus. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia induces cerebral edema are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated, at least in part, by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. We also show that CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which hypoxia induces cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this potentially life-threatening condition. The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in this area. We illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that are required for the direct conversion of nonvascular cells into ECs is unknown. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. In coordination with endogenous forkhead box protein C2 (FOXC2), ETV2 induces expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the generation of vascular networks for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we report the discovery of two physiological ligands for Alk and Ltk, augmentor-α1 and augmentor-α2. We show that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophore system. We also show that augmentor-α2 and augmentor-β are essential for the development of the zebrafish pigment system. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insights into the physiological function of Alk and Ltk and opens up new avenues for the development of targeted therapies for cancer and pigment disorders. β-cell dysfunction is a major molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D). In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the transcription factor Pax6 was down-regulated and its nuclear localization was lost in STING-βKO β-cells. These findings established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the main cause of seasonal epidemics and occasional pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. The lack of conservation might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we found that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a critical factor in promoting the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of athero-protective therapies. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with the economic and demographic characteristics of the people who live there. Specifically, we find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. We also find that neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Finally, we find that neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward the development of a comprehensive understanding of the physical dynamics of cities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of ZIKV is still unclear. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid production of virions and the short eclipse phase. We also show that the timing of antiviral treatment is critical for the control of the disease. Our results provide a framework for the design of future clinical trials. Coral reefs are in the midst of a mass bleaching event. The underlying causes of this breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic activity of the coral host is the primary driver of the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. This, in turn, leads to a shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont, which promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. In the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes dysfunctional, leading to a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. The dysregulated microbiome, in turn, triggers a regenerative response in the tumor, leading to a vicious cycle. We show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Chemotherapy is a major component of the treatment of breast cancer. However, the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and some patients experience a poor response. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab enhances the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event was instead triggered by a volcanic eruption, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a large-scale climate response.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that most catches come from rivers with high stress levels. We also show that inland fisheries are a critical source of protein for the poor and undernourished. However, the high fishing pressure in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to identify areas that are both productive and under pressure, and thus need special attention in conservation and management. This will be particularly important in the context of climate change, which is expected to increase the frequency of extreme events that can damage fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The use of aqueous electrolytes is a promising strategy for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely refractory to regeneration. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery opens up a new platform for the discovery of factors that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The distribution of recombination rates across a genome is a fundamental property of the genome that is important for understanding the evolution of the genome and the function of the genes it contains. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination rates in a flowering plant, using a population of wild monkeyflowers. We find that the distribution of recombination rates is similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the distribution of recombination rates is a conserved feature of eukaryotic genomes.

The brain is organized in topographically distinct networks, each with its own function. The present study provides a method for the identification of these networks, which can be used to study the function of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is known to regulate translation. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes, which is found on a subset of mRNA molecules. This 5′ cap structure is not found on transfer RNA or ribosomal RNA, and is not required for translation of these RNAs. We propose that this 5′ cap structure may regulate translation of a subset of messenger RNA molecules.

The long-term effects of intensive diabetes treatment on the development of complications are not fully understood. We show that DNA methylation of certain loci in blood cells is associated with glycemia in people with diabetes. This association is maintained over time, suggesting that DNA methylation is a potential mechanism for the metabolic memory observed in people with diabetes.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. The biosynthesis of many of these volatiles is unknown, and the role of nitrogen in the flavor of tomato fruit is not well understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles in Nicotiana benthamiana. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and opens the door to the development of improved tomato cultivars. (Read more)

Global warming and biodiversity loss are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of the Earth’s ecosystems. Here we show that the impacts of these two threats are not independent of each other. We demonstrate that the additional impacts of environmental warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance traits of the species present in the community. Our results highlight the need for a more holistic approach to the conservation of ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit. It is thought to create a map of local space, based on the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is debated. Here, we used portable two-photon microscopes to record the activity of large populations of neurons in MEC and adjacent parasubiculum during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells are anatomically segregated from border, HD, and OV cells. These data suggest that grid cell networks might be largely distinct from those of border, HD, and OV cells. Moreover, grid cells exhibit strong coupling among themselves but weaker links to other cell types. This organization may be important for the formation of grid cell networks. Our results have implications for understanding the formation and function of the hippocampal circuit. (Read more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering in plants. It is likely that the evolution of flowering is not a single event, but rather a series of events, each of which is important for the evolution of the next step. The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we report the existence of a previously unknown type of neuronal formation within the dopamine system. These striosome–dendron bouquets are highly specialized, densely packed, and densely innervated by a variety of other neurons. They are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others. In this paper, we show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust signal of connection. This signal is used by people to understand the connection between themselves and others, and it is used by others to understand the connection between themselves and others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for heart rate regulation. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and is required for the normal function of the SAN. We also show that STIM1 regulates the electrical activity of the SAN by controlling the content of Ca2+ in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. These findings reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the heart and suggest that STIM1 may be a potential therapeutic target for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si can enhance the resistance of rice against the rice leaffolder, a key insect pest of rice. This effect was associated with an increase in the accumulation of Si in rice leaves and the activation of the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect rice against insect herbivores. This study also provides a model for the study of the interaction between Si and JA in plant defense. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the metabolism of ether lipids in macrophages. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome in macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages. They also suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. This may be important for the understanding of the role of ether lipids in the pathogenesis of various diseases.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based biomanufacturing. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are critical design parameters for the delivery of siRNAs to plants. We also show that the delivery of siRNAs to plants is dependent on the DNA nanostructure internalization into the plant cell. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants using DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work will be useful for the development of plant-based biomanufacturing. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is experiencing a global increase in coastal eutrophication, which is driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, most of the world’s largest lakes are drained by small streams, which are often overlooked in nutrient management efforts. We show that small streams can be a significant source of coastal nutrients, especially in the form of dissolved inorganic nutrients. This finding has important implications for the management of coastal ecosystems, as it suggests that small streams may be a major source of nutrients that fuel algal blooms in large water bodies. Our findings highlight the need to consider the role of small streams in coastal eutrophication and to develop strategies to manage them effectively. This article is protected by copyright. We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small set of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environment. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems. We also find that the network’s response to the environment is highly sensitive to the connectivity of the network. This sensitivity is a consequence of the network’s ability to absorb work from the environment.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor disrupt neuronal function and cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes in cortical microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We use a mathematical model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes in microcircuitry are critical for the development of overt EEG paroxysms when the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the same mechanisms may be at play in other autoimmune encephalitis disorders. This may have important implications for the development of new therapies. (PsycInfo Database Record

The history of abrupt climate change is a key topic in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the lack of proxy data and modeling approaches that can link the history of abrupt climate change to the evolution of the Earth system. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to the evolution of the Earth system and that it can be linked to the evolution of the Earth system.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s leading producer of palm oil. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for the palm oil industry. Rather, it is a tool that can be used in combination with other strategies to reduce tropical deforestation.

The exocytosis process is essential for the functioning of all organisms. The exocyst complex is a key regulator of this process. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. This study also provides a model for the study of the regulation of complex biological processes. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In other vertebrates, sex is determined by multiple loci, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we show that the evolution of multiple sex determination loci can result in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics. This modular variation can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of sex determination in vertebrates. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and reactive carbonyl species. These species can damage the retina and are generated by the metabolism of the vitamin A aldehyde, A2E. We show that the presence of iron in the retina can promote the oxidation and degradation of A2E. This finding has implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. The results also suggest that the presence of iron in the retina may be a target for the development of therapeutics for age-related macular degeneration. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is often associated with the loss of morphological and functional adaptations. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is associated with the evolution of modularity in their feeding strategies. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialization is not a dead end, but rather a key process in the diversification of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in the study of human evolution. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is fragmentary, however, and the origin of some of the key derived features of the modern human hand is unclear. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth. One-carbon units are essential for cell growth, and are provided by the folate cycle. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of the folate cycle enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase. We show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer, and that the cancer cell response to the inhibitor is dependent upon the cancer cell’s ability to import glycine. Thus, the folate cycle is a targetable metabolic pathway in cancer.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change and is often associated with negative impacts on people’s livelihoods and health. However, there is a lack of evidence on the impacts of deforestation on people’s diets. This study shows that deforestation can have negative impacts on people’s diets, and that this is likely to be a widespread phenomenon. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and livelihoods.

Modern farm machinery is the key to the success of modern agriculture. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the lack of fixed foraging trails in the past may have been a key factor in the extinction of the sauropods.
